awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Multimodel Bayesian Data-Worth Analysis for Groundwater Remediation Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Groundwater contaminant remediation involves removing subsurface contaminants so that they do not pose unacceptable future risks to humans and the environment. While various remediation methods have been developed, they all face a common challenge that the groundwater environment is complex and cannot be fully understood and characterized with limited amount of time and resources. Hence, given the uncertainty in the characterization of the groundwater environment, the challenge is to design a remediation strategy that has the maximum probability of success or equivalently the minimum probability of failure. A common reason for remediation failure is ignoring model uncertainty. Using a single model for remediation design may lead to overconfidence in the predictive capability of the model and thus to increased probability of failure. The proposed research will reexamine the problem of remediation design under model uncertainty by using a multimodel-based data-worth analysis. In other words, multiple models are used to identify and guide the collection of the most valuable data for model evaluation, improvement, and reconstruction. Because of the synthesis between models, remediation designs, and data, the proposed multimodel data-worth analysis for remediation design will provide a transformative platform for scientists, engineers, and decision-makers to systematically investigate all components involved in groundwater remediation. This project will also provide an opportunity for interdisciplinary training of undergraduate and graduate students in the areas of hydrology, computational science, and civil engineering. In addition, the project will engage high school teachers and students in summer schools to gain laboratory and computational experience for understanding the concepts of groundwater contaminant transport and remediation.     

The proposed research has two objectives: to reformulate data-worth analysis for groundwater remediation with consideration of model uncertainty, and to break computational barriers between models and model analysis needed for remediation design. To achieve the first objective, a data-worth analysis will be integrated into a framework of multimodel analysis (also known as model averaging), which will be developed into a new procedure for remediation design that will be compatible with the multimodel data-worth analysis. To achieve the second objective, an accurate but cheap-to-evaluate surrogate of the models will be developed and then used for the data-worth analysis and remediation design under uncertainty. The Bayesian approaches (theoretical and computational) will be used for achieving both the objectives. While the proposed method of multimodel Bayesian data-worth analysis is general and can be applied to any remediation method, it will be integrated with the recently developed engineered injection and extraction method, a promising technique for in-situ remediation. The proposed methods will be evaluated in a two-prong strategy using synthetic and real-world modeling problems. The real-world problem involves uranium contamination at the Naturita Site, Colorado, and nitrogen contamination at the Indian River County, Florida. The synthetic study will mimic the real-world problem to the extent possible so that insights gained from the synthetic study can be used directly for the real-world modeling. This project will provide scientific support for on-going environmental remediation and monitoring at the two field sites as well as other contaminated sites.

por.por_cntn:
Contaminants (e.g., agricultural fertilizers, domestic waste, and industrial waste) can enter subsurface environments through multiple pathways to contaminate groundwater, which is a major source of our drinking water supply. Groundwater contamination poses a threat to not only the environment but also public health. An example problem of groundwater contamination is that caused by per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), as shown in the movie entitled ?Dark Waters?. Many contaminants cannot be degraded or removed in natural environments even after a long period of time. For example, PFAS is called ?forever chemicals?, because it is not naturally degradable. Therefore, engineering approaches are always needed for remediation of groundwater contaminants, so that they do not pose unacceptable future risks to humans and the environment.

All remediation methods face a common challenge that the groundwater environment is complex and cannot be fully understood or characterized using a limited amount of data and information available for remediation design. This lack of data and information causes uncertainty, i.e., it is uncertain whether a remediation design is effective and efficient. In other words, due to the uncertainty, a realistic remediation strategy is to achieve the maximum probability of success or equivalently the minimum probability of failure. A common reason for remediation failure is due to ignoring model uncertainty, which is referred to the situation that a system may be represented by multiple models but it is uncertain which model is the right one to be used for remediation design. Using a single model for remediation design may lead to overconfidence in the predictive capability of the model and thus to increased probability of failure.

This project reexamined the problem of remediation design under model uncertainty by using a multimodel approach, so that a remediation design can still achieve the maximum probability of success when it is unknown how to choose a model to represent a system of interest. The model-driven remediation design requires inter-disciplinary research in the areas of groundwater hydrology, civil engineering, numerical modeling, applied mathematics, and computational statistics. This project supported three graduate students (two female) and one post-doc, and they received interdisciplinary training when working on the project. The project also published a total of 23 peer-reviewed journal articles, two book chapters, one conference proceeding, and 11 conference abstracts in multiple fields. In addition, we have six manuscripts are under review/revision, one book chapter is in press, and one conference proceeding and one conference presentation will be given in 2022. The project has been productive in terms of publications.

PI Ye worked with two female graduate students, one post-doc, and several no-cost collaborators on this project. We developed a new method of Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) simulation for estimating model evidence, which measures plausibility of multiple models. Based on the model evidence, we further developed a relative model score for evaluating ensemble simulations of environmental models. The relative model score implicitly incorporates the measures of ensemble mean accuracy, prediction interval precision, and prediction interval reliability for evaluating the overall model predictive performance. We also developed a new MCMC approach that improves the nested sampling approach, and sparse-grid methods were used for surrogate modeling to reduce computational cost. These methods are mathematically general, and theoretically can be applied to any hydrological and environmental models.          

This project also developed several new methods for identifying controlling processes of a system of groundwater flow and solute transport. The identification is important to remediation design, in that a larger weight may be assigned to an important process when developing an objective function that is commonly used for groundwater remediation. The identification methods explicitly consider process model uncertainty, which is referred to the situation that a system process can be represented by several models. The identification is based on global sensitivity analysis, and includes model space as an additional dimension of the random space of sensitivity analysis, which only considers random model parameters in previous studies.  

For coping with model uncertainty in remediation design, we realized that existing methods of evaluating multiple models may not be appropriate for handling model uncertainty of remediation design, because the best model evaluated based on existing data may not be the best model for an effective and efficient design. We developed two different design concepts, and evaluated using real-world data and models. The first approach is a model selection approach that helps identify the ?critical models? within the multimodel ensemble, which particularly govern the design process. The other approach is a model aggregation approach that identifies system designs that meet the remediation objectives for all models of the ensemble. Results show that the model aggregation approach is the more conservative option, which results in reliable designs at the expense of higher pumping rates. This study evaluates these two approaches within the context of multi-model simulation-optimization, providing insights on multi-model simulation-optimization in groundwater management.


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Ming Ye
